content.description: This route climbs the obvious wideness left of Caging the Cobra and then joins the original CTC route, to the top of the formation. It was led with gear up to #5 but could probably be done with smaller gear.

"Then inch by inch out of the grass rose up the head and spread hood of Nag, the big black cobra, and he was five feet long from tongue to tail. When he had lifted one-third of himself clear of the ground, he stayed balancing to and fro exactly as a dandelion tuft balances in the wind, and he looked at Rikki-tikki-tavi with the wicked snake’s eyes that never change their expression, whatever the snake may be thinking of. “Who is Nag?” said he. “I am Nag. The great God Brahm put his mark upon all our people, when the first cobra spread his hood to keep the sun off Brahm as he slept. Look, and be afraid...”

--from 'Rikki Tikki Tavi' by Rudyard Kipling

A fun foray into chimneying with some hand-sized opening moves and an entry-dance to get into the crack. An irresistible feature and a commanding position that's not to be missed.
content.protection: Nothing as big as you might think since the horizontal cracks take plentiful mid-sizes
content.location: Using the ledge systems, pick your way under the wall's namesake Cobra formation out around the corner. Once you've turned it, look up and ahead and the giant cleaved block of 'Nag' is unmissable.

content.description: This climbs the left facing dihedral right of the orange wall. During the FA, a light breeze was blowing straight up the corner and every time I put my hand in the crack, flakes of lichen the size of Komodo Dragon scales were liberated and then elevated by the breeze. The flakes of lichen swirled around my head and thoughts of Indonesia swirled around inside. The route has cleaned up a bit and the rock is excellent.
content.protection: It has been done with a single rack to three. I know somebody that likes a #4 up there. Chain anchors found on the ledge(Dragan Ledge) to the left.
content.location: Start in a short chimney and move through a ramp with a bush(pass bush on the right) and get into the corner proper then stem your way up to the ledge above(Dragan Ledge).

content.description: The obvious roof proves to be the crux.
content.protection: There are bolts on the route but some gear is required. Small single rack will suffice Bolted anchors
content.location: This route is the obvious roof with bolts left of the wide crack, Open Hood.

content.description: Stem up on jugs to first bolt. Scramble up through ledgey terrain to a big double roof. Pull mini roof ,stay strong, then pull larger roof( 10.b) onto easier terrain(5.8). Good rock good fun.
content.location: The start is 75 ft. right of the base of Caging the Cobra 1st pitch. The route tops out below the Chip and Dale ledge

content.description: The Crux is at the roof.
content.protection: Plenty of passive placements, double to three, a four was used on FA but prolly not necessary. Finishes at the Komodo Corner chains
content.location: Obvious right facing corner left of Blake Effect

content.description: Climb the first pitch of Caging the Cobra and right into AHVI Arete in one long pitch(drop your pack off on the Chip and Dale ledge as you go by)then bring your follower up for some coffee. Use some long runners to reduce rope drag.
content.protection: 15/16 bolts QD's and runners Chains on top
content.location: Rap down Caging or AHVI Arete to the ledge

content.description: This is the original line of ascent to the top of the Cobra. As the name implies, some tip-toeing is required, but really this just isn't recommended.

Pitch 1 is easy ledgey terrain gradually steepening, big holds all the way lead to the somewhat heady 5.7 crux right at the top before stepping onto the Chip and Dale ledge.

Pitch 2 starts in the mini dihedral just up and left of the fixed anchors on the ledge and  is fun climbing on great rock. The pitch starts steep and passes a cool horn feature(bomber)up the lower angle face(great rock) under the enormous roof then crosses left over a wide crack then up to the top of the formation. Pulling onto the top is probably the 5.8 crux.
content.protection: QD's for pro. 5 bolts on pitch 1 and 10 or 11 bolts on second pitch. Protect the follower from heinous penjy at the top of pitch 1 with a cam on the ledge.
content.location: Pitch2 starts in the mini dihedral directly below the massive roof that makes up part of the Cobra formation.

content.description:
This is a very fun route with some face climbing and some great crack climbing. Getting into the crack is tough but the crux may lie above on the bolted stretch to the chains.

The name is a play on Brian Cabe's 'Lake Effect' at Cliff Lake and a nod to all the Uinta route developers that came before.
content.protection: 3 bolts at the start and three bolts at the top and cams for the middle, Plenty o' hand jams.It is recommended that you place a cam in the horizontal between the second and third bolt. Single rack to #3 should suffice. Some may appreciate doubles Green to Gold. Chains
content.location: This is the obvious crack line on the left side of the orange wall

content.description: Fun trad line on good rock.
content.protection: Smaller cams and stoppers. Utilizes bolted anchors atop Hemotoxin
content.location: This is the right trending crack in a shallow corner starting at the base of Komodo Corner proper.

content.description: AKA: Right Arm. Awesome route yet a little different than the usual Uinta jug haul. You will find lots of side pull action some slopers and a couple jugs of course. It climbs right up the steep wavy bulgey orange face right of Blake Effect.

climbs.name: Aaron's Hot Venom Injection Arete
climbs.fa: Aaron Summers, Blake Summers, Anthony Russo

content.description: (AHVI Arete) This is the one that drew us in. Mega fun, instant exposure, arête climbing, jug haul, double crux, very well protected, happy good fun times to chains on top of the Cobra.
content.protection: 10 or 11 bolts to chains. The route shares anchors with Caging the Cobra and Charming the Choss' second pitch.
content.location: It is recommended that you ascend AHVI Arete and lower off Caging the Cobra to avoid potential rope drag. Knot the ends...duh, always.
